awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Platform to Help Prevent and Respond to Sexual Assault
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to deliver a platform, primarily for colleges and universities, to both prevent and respond to campus sexual assault. One in five female college students will be sexually assaulted during their college careers.  Only 10% of victims will report the assaults; the remainder, lacking reporting option information and guidance on recovery, will struggle with an aftermath that can lead to academic challenges and abandoned career plans. Among the 10% of reported assaults, many institutions struggle to respond effectively, leading to negative, high-profile headlines. More than 300 colleges and universities are currently under investigation by the United States Department of Education Civil Rights Office for mishandling sexual assault investigations. While colleges and universities are federally mandated to address campus sexual assault, they lack evidence-based methods to prevent and respond to sexual assault. Lawsuits (from victims and the accused), government fines, college safety ratings, and unchanging assault statistics have led to a commercial opportunity for a research-informed platform designed to align campus sexual assault prevention and response tools and resources.

This I-Corps project aims to explore the commercial potential of a research-informed, evidence-based platform to provide comprehensive, uniquely tailored information to support victims of campus sexual assault, aid in prevention efforts, and promote student safety. The heart of the platform is a mobile application with a design informed by qualitative studies with the target audience, and content informed by 15+ years of sexual violence research, and by input from practitioners in this field. This platform addresses sexual assault prevention and response comprehensively by: 1) Providing research-informed guidance for victims and allies available in a smartphone app and on the web; 2) Using a decision-tree approach to help victims understand options and choose a path forward; 3) Delivering interactive assault prevention tools to help reduce the incidence of assault; 4) Giving schools control of the content, to help ensure assaults are correctly managed; and 5) Providing an implementation toolkit, so schools can easily engage students in the platform's campus adaptation.

por.por_cntn:
During the NSF I-Corps program, our team investigated the commercialization potential of a mobile platform (smartphone app + web-app + website + customization capabilities for non-technical college administrators) designed to help colleges and universities improve their ability to prevent and respond to campus sexual assault.

One in five female college students will be sexually assaulted during their college careers. Only 10% of these victims will report the assaults; the remainder, lacking reporting option information and guidance on recovery, will struggle with an aftermath that can lead to acute and chronic health problems, poor academic performance and abandoned education and career goals. And in the 10% of cases where victims do report assaults, many institutions struggle to respond effectively, resulting in negative, high-profile headlines and large legal settlements.

Colleges and universities are federally mandated to address campus sexual assault, but lack evidence-based methods to prevent and respond to sexual assault. This, coupled with continuing student lawsuits, government fines, college safety ratings, and unchanging assault statistics have created a commercial opportunity for a research-informed platform designed to enhance and integrate campus sexual assault prevention and response tools and resources. 

During the I-Corps program our team met with Title IX coordinators, deans, and other senior administrative staff at residential colleges and universities across the US. We examined the problems inherent in existing programming and reporting, to explore the need for a research-informed, evidence-based platform to provide comprehensive, uniquely tailored information to support victims of campus sexual assault, aid in prevention efforts, and promote student safety.

The heart of the uSafeUS platform is a smartphone application (app), with a design informed by qualitative studies with the target audience (students), and content informed by 15+ years of sexual violence research, and by input from law enforcement, campus administrators and rape crisis professionals currently working in the field. The platform addresses sexual assault prevention and response comprehensively by: 1) Providing an up-to-date single source of all resources a student who has experienced an assault might need, as defined by each school; 2) Providing research-informed guidance for victims and allies available in a smartphone app and on the web; 3) Providing a decision-tree approach to help victims and their supporters understand options and choose a path forward; 4) Delivering interactive assault prevention tools to help reduce the incidence of assault by letting users subtly exit potentially risky situations, i.e. leave situations before they become dangerous to warrant a call to police or other authorities; 5) Providing a tool for students to engage peers in their safety when walking alone; 6) Giving colleges and university administration control of the content provided to users, including helpful answers and advice? and to help ensure assaults are correctly managed; and 7) Providing an implementation toolkit, so college and universities can efficiently engage students and the entire campus community in the campus platform adoption.

During the 6 week I-Corps program we conducted 126 interviews with college and university administrators and private high school administrators in 25 states. Eighty-two of these interviews were conducted in person, 27 were conducted via video conference and 17 were conducted by phone.  The outcomes were two-fold.

First, most residential colleges and universities expressed frustration with a lack of resources to expand existing in-person prevention programming. Alongside this, many expressed a desire for enhanced website information for victims. Nevertheless, they struggled to envision how these two areas could be improved by a student smartphone app. It became clear that we needed to do more work to educate potential customers on how a customizable app could help solve their problems. (Note: this need for education was also created by earlier and much less effective apps that had been marketed to colleges.)

Second, we heard a fairly consistent concern that students needed to begin learning about ways to protect themselves from sexual assault and harassment in high school; many interviewees suggested that college was too late to begin this task.
